div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: OCCIDENT v. ORIENT.
div.p:
The anti-Asiatic riots in the United States have suddenly assumed a shape which affects Great Britain far more seriously than did those of a few months ago. In the case of the anti Japanese agitation, our interest was only contingent; in that of the anti-Hindoo agitation which has just culminated in rioting at Bellingham, our interest is direct and unavoid able. A Hindoo is as much a British subject as an Englishman or Sootsman; whatever affects him injuriously in foreign countries is as much the concern of the British Government as if it offected injurioasly a man born in the British Isles instead of India. It is, therefore, a matter of peculiar importance to the Empire when the anti-Asiatie feeling in the West of America turns against the comparatively few Hindoos who dwell in the small frontier town near the northern boundary of the State of Washington. It seeins probable that the Indian Colony there is a relio of the unfortunate emigration movement which drew a
P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O

F. G. DAVIDSON, Suez.
number of Indians to Canada some time ago. When they found that the climate was too severe for them, many, if not most, of the Indians went home of their own accord or had their passages paid for them; some, however, seem to have settled on the Pacifie slope. They were probably quiet and inoffensive, but industrious. At any rate, no credence need be given to the report spread by the anti-Asiatic agitators that white women were pashed into gutters and insalted on street-cars. A small community of new-comers, living precariously on sufferance in a foreign land, do not generally go out of their way to draw down the wrath of their hosts, and risk a possible lynching and certain banishment by attacking those who outnumber them by thousands to one.

It so happens that the City Cooncil of Bellingham have acted in an unexpectedly creditable manner, in comparison with the course pursued by the Corporation of San Francisco. They have sworn in special officers to protect the strangers within their gates; but those strangers are already leaving for Vancouver. In British territory the Asiatic may not always be very welcome ; bat life, limb, and property are secure. It remains to be seen, however, whether the incident will end in this fashion. The feeling against the Orientals is still simmering in the Occident; it may boil over again at any moment. The Federal Government may profess themselves to be powerless to deal with a recaloitrant State in this matter; and ansatisfactory though that ples may be, it is not to be denied that the Americans can answer any protest which the British Government may make by a very effective "ta quoque." Much the same constitutional situation occurs in the British Empire, and the Imperial Government finds itself powerless to take any effective measures. Neither in Australia nor in South Africa are Asiatics desired, and small distinction is drawn in those Bountries under the Union Jack between Asiatics who are British subjects and Asia tios who are not. In both the colour bar is more power ful than the pass of Imperial citizenship. The Natal Restriction Act, for instance, which has become the foundation of all the Colonial exclusion laws now in force, does not specifically exclude Asiaties; it simply forbids the entry into the Colony of paupers or persons likely to become a public charge, idiots lunatios, diseased, immoral and criminal persons, and anybody who, when asked, fails to write in some European language application for admission to the Colony.

For all practical purposes such an Act hardly operates against any but Asiaties. And it is probably small consolation to the Hindoo to remember that he is exeluded from a British Colony, not as a British subject, but as an undesirable person whom the low places in the same category as lunatics and criminals. The poll-tax which prevails in other places is a more direct means of attaining the same end. The Asiatic is given to understand that he is not wanted in British Colonies; and this operates especially in countries where a white population rules an aboriginal coloured race. Here again, it is not very comforting to the civilised emigrant from India, who prides himself on his ancestors and on being a British subject, to remember that he is classed with the Kaffir or with those dying tribes of Australia which have not even a distinctive name of their own. The British Government have protested in the past against such exelusion laws, and have vetoed some of them on occasion; but neither their protest nor their veto has been of any effect. A sel-governing State of the Ernpire has, in practice, the power to say whom it will accept or refuse within its borders; and the admittedly impotent attitude of Lord Elgin in the latest case of British Indians in the Transvaal only tells again an oft-told tale. In these circumstances, it may be imagined how little force any representations from Mr. Bryce will have at Washington. The whole question of racial competition is of such appalling difficulty and complexity that one can do little more at present than grope towards a tentative solution, and deprecate any such inflammatory tactics as have been pursued on the Pacific slope of the United States. A definite issue is raised; unhappily, no definite answer can yet be given.

div.head: Training Ship
div.p: The "Amiral Miaonlis" a Greek training ship for marine cadets has just arrived at Port Said.

div.head: Israelite Fast.
div.p: To-morrow being the occasion of the great Israelite Fast, the Banks and Minet-el-Bassal market will be closed.

div.head: Journal Case
div.p: The procés against the native journals came before the Native Tribunal yesterday morning. Judgment was adjourned.

div.head: Cramophobia
div.p: Fathalla Waked, a chemist of Cairo, has been fined P.T. 500 by the Native Tribunal for playing a gramophone after mid-night.

div.head: Plague Bulletin
div.p: During the last twenty four hours two fresh cases have been reported at Alexandria and eight recoveries. There are at present eight cases under treatment.

div.head: Train Fatality.
div.p: A native, Ahmed Abdel-Gaffir. by name, was mounting & train in motion, when be slipped and fell on the rails. The train passed over his body, and death was immediate.

div.head: Assassin's Arresteret
div.p: The secret police of Cairo have arrested a certain Nicolas G. Koloris, who killed one of his parents in order to steal money. The assassin took to flight and was condemned to death by the local Native Tribonal on December 15 last. Koloris has been bronght to Alexandria under strong escort.

div.head: Public Works Ministry.
div.p: By a service order of the Public Works Ministry Abdel Rahman Effendi Aly has been appointed provisionally as engineer to the Zifta Circle of Irrigation at L.E. 17 per mensem. By the same order Youssef Effendi Pahmy Mohamed and Hassan Effendi Fouad have been appointed to the same circle at L.E. 18 per month

div.head: Sudden Death
div.p: The death is reported of a Jewish resident of Alexandria as occuring under somewhat exceptional circumstances. Resorting on Sunday night to a house of ill-fame, the man, whose age was 85 years, asked for a glass of water, and immediately after drinking the same he fell down in a fit and died before medical aid could be rendered.

div.head: Suspected Plague Cases
div.p: Three cases of suspected plague on board in-coming vessels have been disproved by observation during the last few days. On the arrival of the S.S. "Sydney" in Alexandria the case of the death a child of seven years, in which plague had been diagnosed, was examined into and negatived, while other cases aboard the S.S. "Minieh" and 8.8. "Circassia" were also proved to have been wrongly diagnosed.

div.head: Tanzim Motor Destroyed.
div.p: Yesterday at about 3 p.m a tram ran into a Tanzim automobile, in the rue Vieux Caire which was leaving the Public Works building. The chauffeur escaped uninjured, but the motor was completely destroyed. A delay of 35 minutes was cansed while a shawish was being discovered! It is said that the Tramway Com pany intend to bring a case against the Tanzim owing to the great annoyance and loss caused by the stoppage.

div.head: At Petersburg
div.p: Russia also wants to assimilate the important discoveries of this century-not only in what concerns the military improvements but as well as in what appertains to the progress of the mind. The authorization has consequently been granted to the Berlitz School of Languages, Cairo 1 Bharia Kamel, Alexandria 12 rue Rosette--to open a branch at Petersburg. This new sehool which is already well frequented will certainly follow the example given by its 300 senior schools and like them will be patronized by the success based on gratitude and esteem. (Apvr.)

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Moorish Prince" left Malta on the 14th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Wednesday the 18th September
The S.S. "Cyprian Prince" with passengers and general cargo left Manchester on the 13th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 29th September.
The S.S. "Trojan Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 15th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 1st October.
The 8.. "Indian Prince" left Antwerp on the 16th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 1st October.
The S.S. "Andalusian" left last night from Malta and is due here on the 20th inst, with passengers and mails.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPE PATHE
div.p: Voici l'intéressant programme de cette se maine :

Séville et ses environs, grande scène de plein air ; la fée des roches ; le gendarme a du flair ; pochard -malgré lui; les débuts d'un patineur ; Discipline et Humanité, grande scène dramatique et réaliste ; un sculpteur express, scède à transformations ; diseuse de bonne aventure, seene de ger re; silhouette animée, scène à trucs; la Vengeance do Forgeron, grande scène dramatique en 60 tableaux ; au premier jour; et le Bombardement de Casablanca, scene absolument authentique prise sur le vif.

div.head: THE IRRAGATION SERVICE
div.p: REPORT FOR 1906.

div.head: THE NILE SUPPLY AND SEASON
div.p: In his report upon the irrigation service in Egypt and the Sudan for the year 1906 Sir William Garstin says :

The year 1906 showed a decided improvement, as regards river discharges, over its immediate predecessors. For seven years previous, the levels throughout the year had been persistently below the average, and in one case the river in summer fell to a point lower than any that had previously been recorded. Last year the maximum height registered was that of an average, but not of a good flood. At the end of 1905 the prospects for the following season were far from satisfactory, as the gauge readings at Wadi Halfa averaged some 40 centimetres below the normal river-level for that period of the year. Everything seemed to point to a continuance of the conditions that had so long ruled, and to indicate another year of poor supply. Early and abnormal rains, however, in the months of February and March brought a timely supply down the Blue Nile, apd materially changed the aspect of affairs -- converting what must otherwise have been a bad summer into a good one.

On May the 1st the Blue Nile at Roseires stood 1.13 metres above the average of previous years, and about this time the Sobat commenced to rise. Throughout the month in question the increase in both rivers was insig. nificant, but in June the levels of the Blue Nile rose rapidly. The rise in the Sobat also continued, but at a normal rate. These increases in the south did not, however, produce a similar effect in the north. From the commencement of May the river-levels at Wadi Halfa commenced to fall. This drop continued until the middle of June, when the effect of the annual steady rise began to make itself apparent. This rise, therefore, as regards Egypt was a late one, and until the middle of July was very slow. Subsequent to this last date, the increase was normal, and the rise of the river was continuous until the 18th of Sep tember, when the maximum height of 15 pics 20 kirats was registered upon the Aswan gauge. The fall of the river was also normal, and at the end of 1906 the levels at Wadi-Halfa were better than had been the case, at that season, in any one of the seven preceding years. Mr. Webb describes the measures taken for ensuring the effective distribution of water throughout the year, so I will not further allude to them. I must, however, say some thing about the effective manner in which he, and his staff, regulated and controlled the water stored in the Aswan Reservoir.

div.head: THE NILE RESERVOIR
div.p: The regulation of the dam sluices is a most intricate business, demanding continual care and study of the river to the south. The sluices last year were so skilfully manipulated that the levels of the river downstream of the dam mere steadily increased, as the summer advaneed, so as to correspond with and meet the increase in the demand for water in the north. The daily amount added to the river from the reservoir varied from six to twenty millions of cubic metres. It is difficult to speak too highly of the work here done by Mr. Maodonald, and his assistant, Mr. Cooper. Throughout the summer months, thanks to their labours, as the demand in Egypt increased, there was always more water forthcoming with which to meet it. Until the period of severe pressure (which occurs annually in July, just before the arrival of the flood) arose, water was plentiful every where, and the distribution gave but little tronble.

div.head: DEATH OF MR. DENMEN J.P.
div.p: We regret to record the death of Mr. T.W. Denman, J.P., which occurred recently at Retford, and we offer to his family and relations our sincere condolences. The Denman family, of wbom members have been residents in Egypt for several years, have been land owners in West and East Retford and neigh. bourhood for some hundred years. One of the family, Nicolas Denman of East Retford - whose old timbered house stood on or near the side of the national infants school, Grove Street, for about 300 years-married secondly Anne, daughter of Humphrey Herey, Esq. and sister of Sir John Hercy, Grove Hall, who at her brother's death, succeeded to the manor of West Retford, where they afterwards resided Her descendant was Anne Denman, who it is stated was the grandmother of two Queens of England —Queen Mary II and Queen Annewhile her sister Barbara married Edward Darrel Esq., of Horkstowe Manor, Lincolnshire.

Of their five sons the youngest and sole survivor was John Darrel, B.A., M.D., who dying childless, founded the noble charity of the Holy Trinity, West Retford. Thus Mr. Thomas William Denman was a collateral descendant of the original Dennan family as well as of the founder of the above named institution. Mr. Denman was proprietor in West Retford of some of the original lands, which were descended from his ancestor. He acted as solicitor to the Trinity "Hospital estate, and clerk to the Church and Poor Fond in West Retford.

div.head: Source of wealth
div.p: Many other things have contributed to the sound economic condition of Egypt. The adjective "economio" implies not merely that which pertains to the regulation of a country's management, but denotes equally freedom from wastefulness and extravagance. I need not dwell on the regularity and the reforms introduced, for they are known to all who have followed Lord Cromer's brilliant carcor, nor need I refer in great detail to the excellence of the financial system now. 80 firmly establis. hed, yet it is useful to point out that the latest Trade and Customs retums show a higher total than any ever previously attained, the total value of merchandise imported and exported in 1906 amounting to £48,888,000, as against less than half that sum in 1896. The revenue of Egypt has Nkewise steadily expanded - during the last five years at an average annual rate of £553,900 from £9,675,000 in 1887 to £15,374,000 in 1906. There is as well a sum of over elever millions sterling standing to the credit of the reserve fund, while the total amount of the Egyptian debt now in the hands of the public is but £87,416,000, and the interest charge borne by the taxpayers but £3,368,000, as compared with £96,457,000 and £4,268,000 in 1883, when the British first occupied the country and began their beneficent work of reform. And this result has been achieved notwithstanding progressive and very considerable reductions in taxation. It is noteworthy also that with the country's prosperity the population has increased from 6,814,000 in 1882 to 9,734,000 in 1897 (the date of the last census), and that it now approximates in the Delta provinces to 650 inhabitants to every square mile, or donble the estimated density of population in the United Kingdom. Labour is consequently abundant and continues cheap, while the Egyptian labourers are remarkable for their vigour and industry.

If in the foregoing preliminary pages I have refrained from giving statistical tables in support of the several assertions of fact. I have done so not because there is insufficient material from which to compile them, but rather because I have desired by a simple olear and cogent statement, not unduly burdened with figures, to disabuse the public mind of any possibly existing, though latent, impression that the recent Alexandria Bourse troubles reflect any semblance of unsoundness in the State. The facts I have inarshalled should dispel once and for all any lingering mists of doubt on this score, and having thus cleared the ground I will proceed to show why I hold that a golden opportunity now exists in Egypt for the bona fide British investor, and I shall venture to indicate, quoting chapter and verse for my beliefs, certain safe investments.

To the far sighted the recent Bourse troubles will appear but a blessing in disguise. Not only was a larger quantity of shares placed last winter on the Alexandria market than the members of the European colonies in Egypt could absorb, but practically no assistance was forthcoming from the numbers of wealthy natives, for these gentlemen limit themselves almost entirely, when they do invest their sav. ings, to the purchase of agricultural lands. Not having sufficient ready-money capital, European purchasers of the new shares multiplied their holdings by having recourse to the old expedient of borrowing from their bankers, depositing as cover first their gilt | edged bearer securities-e.g., National, and Agricultural, Bank of Egypt shares--and final ly, as collateral cover, their newly-purchased shares. Seeing that the spirit of speculation was abroad, and that the concurrent and extraordinary boom in building plots must sooner or later, bring disaster to many, the principal Banks were at first chary of lending any but nominal sums on shares in the new companies, and finally refused altogether to lend anything at all on them. Driven into a corner when a few local failures caused the speculative bubble to burst, operators were not only frequently unable to pay off their loans, or provide fresh marginal cover, but in many cases found them selves saddled with lines of new shares (to say nothing of building lands)which had becomeprao tically, though but temporarily, unmarketable Thus they were constrained to allow the Banks to protect themselves by selling the securities deposited with them as guarantee for advances and, as sound shares like those of the National Bank of Egypt and of the Agricultural Bank were chief among the securities readily saleable, the consequence was that these highclass shares were thrown in large numbers on The market, with the inevitable result that National Banks tell from 281, at which figure they stood at the beginning of the present year to below £17, while Agrionltural Banks nenoted from £10 to 77. And it is noteworthy that the fall was aggravated by many of the shares be ing sold in Paris at the time when that Bourse was already depressed on account of the serious disturbances among the wine-growers in the extreme south of France. The financial position in Egypt thus became almost unique scarcity (of money) in the midst of plentywondrons prosperity and yet dearth of funds. (To be continued.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Moe Perry, under-secretary to the Public Works department, will leave for Europe on the 20 inst.
M. Scotidis has left Athens for Smyrna, where he will stay for a short time.
The Rev. J.H. Molesworth, M.A. Chaplain of All Saints Cairo, arrived on September 16 and is residing at present at Rossmore House.
Socrate Bey Spiro, general secretary of the Porta and Light Administration, is expected here in a few days.

A marriage has been arranged, and will shortly take place, between Francis Hubert Manley of Spofforth Hall, Yorks, son of the late George Manley, of Spofforth, and Gladys, only child of Sir Alfred Moloney, K.C.M.G., J.P., late Governor of Trinidad, now of Cefntilla Court, Usk, Monmouthshire, and the late Constance Lady Moloney.

The marriage took place yesterday of Me. Giuseppe Volpini, Advooste at the Court of Appeal, to Miss Rachel Guttieres Pegna, daughter of Mr. Albert Guttieres Pegna, a partner of the well-known firm G. Marons and Company

Mr. Georges M. Mobayed, son of Mr. Michel Móbayed, a prominent nember of the Syrian community of Alexandrix, returned this morning after a brilliant completion of his course of studies at the Crystal Palace School of Engineering, where he has been awarded the certificate of honour for six certificates obtained in the school course.

Among those who arrived this morning by the M.M mail boat were Mr. Durand, Captain Percival, Countess Zizinia, Dr. Fonquet, Mr. Macintyre, Mr. and Mrs. Bepedueci, Mr. Papa zian, Mr. Sheldrick, Mr. Lebland, and Mrs. Charlton.

div.head: THE "OLIVEMOOR."
div.p: The weather conditions are to-day considerably more favourable to the salvage operations, and the pump, the breakage of which necessitated the salvage steamer's return to harbour the night before last, having been repaired, operations are now being continued withont interruption. This morning seventy men were sent off to the wrecked vessel to jettison cargo, and on their arrival they immediately commenced throwing overboard general cargo, including cases of whiskey, firebrieks, coal, etc., etc. It is considered that, should the present favourable conditions continne, the vessel will be got off the rocks during the course of Thursday. The wind is now blowing chiefly from the north, the sen is calm, and the swell bas subsided considerably.

div.head: SHIP BUILDING IN EGYPT
div.p: Yesterday morning the first of the barges built by the Khedivial Mail Steamship, and Graving Dooks Company, Ltd., to the order of the Salt and Soda Company, Ltd., was launch ed trom the Khedivial Company's shipbuilding 1 yard at Alexandria, the launch being most Successfully performed in the presence of several interested onlookers. The entire work of construction and fitting of these barges, which have a length of 180 feet and an average speed of eight to nine knots an hour, is being done by the Khodirial Mail Company, and the barge launched yesterday gave amplo evidence of the excellence and thoroughness of the work. The "Salt," by which name the barge is to be known, will be ready for use in about four weeks' time, and yesterday afternoon the company commenced work upon her sister vessel the "Soda," which will be ready for launching in abont six weeks. After the launch the comIpany adjourned to the S.S. "Osmanieh" where refreshments were served and the success of the "Salt" was toasted with unanimous oordiality. QUAIL SHOOTING ACCIDENT.

div.head: QUAIL SHOOTING ACCIDENT
div.p: We are sorry to learn, that Professor L. Poggetti, director of the Italian school, was badly injured while quail-shooting with a party of friends at Aboukir on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Poggetti and a friend were outside the cirole of shooters with the object of pioking off quail missed by other guns, the former crouching behind a heap of stories. Observing a qual flying low Mr. Poggetti rose to fire, but his companion brought dowh the bird before he could shoot, and Mr. Poggetti received a part of the charge full in the face. The damaging shot bad been fired from a distattee of only 15 to 20 yards, and infliotod considerable injury on Mr. Poggetti in left ey being badly affected. First aid was rendered at the house of Mr. Eynaud and Mr. Poggatti was afterwands conveyed to his own hom where he was attended by Dr. Borghi and Dr. Danaprindie. It is feared that the professor will lose the sight of his left eye.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: We are desired by the honorary secretary of the Alexandria Swimming Club to remind our readers that the fifth annual aqustio sports of the club will be held on Saturday, the 12th of October, at Gabbary. The entries for the various events promise to be even more numerous than last year, and a record success is guaranteed by the energy displayed by the hon. secretary and the committee in the organisation of the meeting.

Members who have not as yet sent in their entry fortas-should do so at once and should also pot in an appearance, at the baths on Saturday or Sunday next, at any time from 3.30 p.m., for the purpose of having their times taken. Non-members desiring to compete in the sports, will kindly communicate with the Hon. See on or böföre Saturday next the 21st inst. Amongst other events the following will take place 60 yards Senior Handicap for "Sirdar" medal Senior and Junior Diving Championship, Juniors Race, Veterans Race and a 300 yards Invitation Team Race between the following-- Alexandria Rowing Club, Club International Canottieri, Club Nantique Français Deutscher Sportverein, Polo Mateh, Tag-of-War, Planging Championship, Walking the Pole, in fancy costume, Obstacle Race, Blindfold Race, Cock fighting
A special prize will be presented by the club to the member producing the six best photographic snapshots of the sports.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: INCAPABLES Y. INCOMPETENTS. (FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

A match between the above mentioned teams took place on the A.C.C. ground on Friday afternoon. The Incapables were suitably led by Mt. H. P. Carver while a natural course of selection devolved the captainey, of the Incompetents op Mr. Leslie Reid. The Inanpa bles won the toss and made bat a fooble display until the arrival of Carver Bros, who made the ball spin as merrily as they usually do the cotton, until finally canght out by the Finance Department

The Incompetents fulfilled the hopes of their sponsors until the arrival of Mr. R Barnard on the scene, who capably seeonded by Capt. Potts succeeded in all but putting matters on an even keel, Mr. Barand gave an astonishing ly dashing display to the tone of 61 compiled in less than half an hour.

The fact remains that the fortune of the Incapables was remarkable in winning this match against the exceptional bowling of Messrs D. Morice and L. Reid ably supported by the fielding of Messrs. Etherington Smith, and Borton. Messrs. Leslie, Beid, and Monica were at home before, during and after the match to their numetons friends and admirers, who spends most enjoyable afternoon

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Ce matin le marché a débuté ayeg berrcoup d'animation, pour se calmer un peu plus tard et finir terne, mais assez soutenu. Les valeurs dirigeantes ont été complètement délaisades, au profit de quelquesautres d'ordre, secondaire parmi lesquelles figurent au premier rang.. par ordre d'importance dans les transactions, la Delta Land, les Estatės, rurbaine et les Ritz, Hotels. Beaucoup de bruit, en somme, pour. peu de chose. C'est le Caite qui vend, comme cela ressort assez clairement du fait que ce sont les arbitragiktek qui travaillent et que la tenue da marché dans la capitale a été mapifestement plus faible qu'ici au cours de ces dernières séances. Sur notre place il y effort général pour maintenit les cours. tendance est ideoise.

Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, la National Bank flbeltit encore de 20 3/16 20 1/8; la Privilégiée Delta Light reste à 9 11/16 vendeurs, mais la Dividende s'inscrit en nouvelle baisse d'une demi-live * 7 1/2 ; quant a lohi gation Orédit Poncier, l'offre qui suit ordinaire, ment le tirage du 16, ramène le prix de 299 297 pour l'ancienne et de 253 à 252 pour la nouvelle.

En recut également les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 149 1/2X142 vendeurs et la Land Bank de 7 3/16 a 7 1/8, tandis que les Lots Turcs progressent de 158 160, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 8/4 à 13 15/16, et l'Urbaine de 8 1/82 à 8 1/16. Le Banco di Roma se consolide # 104 1/2-105. 19

Les fluotuations ne sont pas moins inégales sur les titres de moindre envergure : ainsi la Salt and Soda s'avance de 18 1 18/3, 1. Delia Land de 1 5/8 #1 21/32 acheteurs et les Rita Hotels de 17/324 9/16, tandis que le fonda teur United rétrograde de 13/4 à 1 28/32, l'Aboukir de 27/6 * 27/8, la Building Lands de 2 1/82 à 2, et les Estates de 21/32 1 vendeurs.
Rien à signaler sur le reste de la cote hi comme transactions, ni comn e variations.

A la nouvelle enchère publique de ce matin, 100 Industrial and Building (Karam) ont été. achetés au prix de 28/64 et 70 Aboukit vendus à 27/3. Il s'agit encore d'une exécution ordon née à l'encontre de la Bonrse and Banking,

On assure que le marché x terme n'est pas près d'etre rétabk. Nombre de courtiers ayant encore des différences & payer, les antres atten dent évidemment d'être regtés pour consentir de nouveaux crédits et traiter des affaires 1 terme. C'est tout juste, parait-il, l'il y a soft samment de eonfiance réciproque pour traite comptant. La crise se trouve ainsi paral également le marché 1 terme "sur leque tablait surtout pour une reprise.
Demain étant jour de chômage pour la corbeille des valeurs à l'occasion du grand Jeline Israélite, notre prochain bulletin ne pataltra que jeudi 19 courant.

Vendredi prochain, M° Longhi donners, & son bénéfice, dans la grande salle de fêtes qui lui a été graciebseinent offerte, Lun bal d'enfants, qui ne manquera certes pas d'attrait. Il sera distribue des confetti et serpentins aux enfants et pour terminer le joli programme, il y aans une valse pour les adultes. Nous souhaitons grande succès à M Longbi qüi se donne toujours benneoup de peine pour la jeunesse
Samedi prochain, dernière grande fête dei nuit de la saison, avec feu d'artifice enperhe qui sera le plus joli de la saison

div.head:
Ciculaire H. De Vried et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITUES
div.p: Le Caire, Lundi 16 Septembre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est resté invarié à 4 pour cent.
Samedi, aa Stock Exchange, les cours sont restés invariés : le Consolidé à 82 1/4, l'Unifiée 101 1/2, la National Bank à 20 1/4, la Daïra à 128/4, l'Agricole à 8 1/4 et la Delta Light à 9 3/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a été soutenu à 688 et la Banque d'Athènes à 112. Les Lots Turcs ont gagné 1 franc à 167.

Ici, en dépit des nouvelles favorables, qui nous parviennent des marchés européens, la situation ne s'est pas améliorée ce matin et la Bourse ne parvient guère à secolier son inae. tivité. La séance a été très faible aveo affaires quasi-nalles, surtout sur nos valeurs dirigeantes.
Les valeurs parement locales ont été légèrement plus animées, quoique avec tendance à la lourdeur et sans transactions importantes.

On prétend que cette faiblesse provient de La liquidation du portefeuille d'une maison de banque dont le récentsauvetage est dans toutes les mémoires, en même temps que de l'exécytion de quelques ordonnances de référé.
Constatons pour bonne note que l'immense majorité des cours sont restés invariés et que parmi les quelques titres traités il y en a plusieurs qui ont terminé en léger progrès.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, l'Agricole peu traitée, mollit à 8-8 1/16 La Banque d'Orient se tasse à 116-117.

La Delta Light Railways est ramenée a 911/16. Les obligations anciennes du Crédit Foncier fléchissent à 999 et les nouvelles à 254. La Béhéra reperd 1/4 à 20. L'Allotment, mieux tenne, progresse à 2 1/4-5/16, tandis que sa part s'alourdit à P.T. 59.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich remontent à 13 13/16. Les Baehler sont moins soutenus à 6. L'Upper Egypt est en bon progrès à 2 7/8. Les National Hotels rétrogradent à 2 1/2 et la part à P.T. 32.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la New Egyptian est mieux disposée à 14/. - 13. Les Estates sont soutenus à 0 5/8 - 11/16 et leur part avance à 3. Les Abdy se consolident à 01.29/16 et les Hooker à 0 3/8 - 7/16. L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail recule à 20,9.

M. Paul Leroy-Beaulieu, dans l'"Economiste Français," cherchant la cause de la cherte actuelle du loyer de l'argent, croit la trouver dans l'impossibilité de l'épargne mondiale à répondre aux besoins du commerce et de l'industrie, lorsqu'ils sont en plein développement.

"Prenant pour base le tableau des émissions annuelles, il constate que le chiffre des de mandes de capitaux correspondant à l'année 1906 s'est élevé à 26 1/2 milliards de frane, ou plus exactement 16 milliards en nombre rond si l'on en déduit le montant des conversions, qui ne sont pas à proprement parler de nouveaux appels an crédit. Ce chiffre est sensiblement plus élevé que celui de la moyenne des années précédentes et M. Leroy Beaulieu estime que le monde civilisé ne fournit pas, à l'heure actuelle, une somme d'épargnes annuelles destinées aux placements en valeurs mobilières de toute nature, qui atteigne 16 milliards de francs, de sorte que, suivant lui, un appel de 16 milliards en une année ne peut pas être satisfait."
Evaluant l'épargne de différents pays, il ar rive pour la France an chiffre de 1,500 millions.

"Pour les autres pays M. Leroy-Beaulieu évalue "grosso modo" et à vue de nez cette épargne annuelle à 1,500 millions également pour l'Allemagne, à 2 milliards ponr l'Angle terre, à 700 millions pour la Belgique et la Hollande ensemble, à 800 millions pour l'Autriche-Hongrie, à 300 millions pour l'Italie, à 250 millions pour l'Espagne et le Portugal, à 200 millions pour les pays scandinaves, à 500 millions pour la Russie, à 200 millions pour le reste de l'Europe, à 3 milliards pour les EtatsUnis, enfin à 500 millions pour le reste da monde. Tout cela ne fait que 11 1/2 millards à peine. Que l'on force même quelques chiffres, si l'on veut, et qu'on arrive ainsi à 13 on 14 milliards, ce sera tout le bout du monde. Ce sera encore, en tout cas, bien inférieur aux 16 milliards demandés.
"Et voila, conclut M. Leroy-Beaulien, l'explication de la crise financière actuelle."
Carnet de l'actionnaire

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
GUN PRACTICE CAUSES PANIC.
THE COAST QUIET.

div.p: M. Regnault, the French Minister at Tangier, has arrived here in order to consult General Drude. Admiral Philibert reports that everything is quiet all along the coast. Gun practice at Mazagan on board the "Conde" caused a panic in the town: the people rushed to the mosques : many were trampled upon in the confusion: the Consuls have protested to the French Consul against the "Conde" not having given previous warning.(Reuter)

The Chaouias emissaries have accepted all | the conditions of General Drude. They desire to retorn and appear again on Thursday with the Kaids and delegates from each tribe in order to make a general surrender.(Havas)

All is calm. The Minister M. Regnault and Admiral Philibert have landed, and were met on the quay by General Drude and his principle officers. M. Regnault complimented the General on the work accomplished, and afterwards visited the ambulance camp and was presented to the Sheriff of Casablanca.(Havas)

div.head:
THE DANGER OF MODERNISM.
A VATICAN ENCYCLICAL.

div.p: The Vatican has published an important Encyclical declaring modernism as generally dangerous and a synthesis of all heresy, ordering the removal of modernists from Catholic professorships, the institution of a censorship over every diocese, the prohibition of ecclesiastical congress except on rare occasions, and announcing other reactionary measures.(Reuter)
An Encyclical letter from the Pope condemns modernism, and enumerates measures for combating it.(Havas)

div.head:
CHOLERA IN RUSSIA
INCREASE OF EPIDEMIC.

div.p: There have been 1663 cases of cholera at Astrakan since the outbreak and 849 deaths. The cholera is increasing at Samara, Nijni Novgorod and elsewhere.(Reuter)

div.head:
THE ANTWERP STRIKES
ROTTERDAM NOW EFFECTED

div.p: 1000 more English strike-breakers arrived here to-day, but many, tiring of confinement on board ship are continually leaving. The strike has spread to Rotterdam.(Reuter)
Mr. Edwards, member of the House of Commons, is presiding over the International Miners' Congress.(Havas)
The Socialist Congress has been opened.(Havas)

div.head:
VALUBABLE FINDS OF PAPYRI
OLD GREEK PLAYS RECOVERED
div.p: The Paris "Debate" publishes, a long and interesting article by Professor Maspero, describing the discovery of fragments of a number of Greek plays by Menander amongst the rains of the village of Komisbagon.

These fragments are written on papyri, and have been partially deciphered by M. Lefebvre, whose predecessor, M. Quibell, had already disinterred various instruments and articles belonging to the early Coptic era in this district. About fifteen months ago M. Lefebvre came upon a few dilapidated shreds of papyrus, on which he at once recognised pieces of dialogue of an unknown Greek play. He at once ap plied for fonds sufficient to enable him to ex tend his explorations, and bought up a whole quarter of the village. A few days' work brought to light some thirty rolls of Greek and Coptio papyrus and several manuscript folios with the name of Menander.

The discovery was kept secret for nearly a year to give the savants time to decipher the manuscripts and continue their excavations. The family papers founds with the manuscripts belonged to a local lawyer who lived in the sixth century, whose property seems mostly to have been situated at Antinoe, which is at some distance from Aphroditopolis the Lesser, I as Komishagon was then called. Consequently if any further fragments exist they are more likely to be found at Antinöe. With indomitable patience, M. Lefebvre has reconstituted and translated thirteen hundred and twentyeight verses, and he judges that they belong to four comedies-The Epitrepontes ("The Judgment"), The Perikeiromène ("The Shorn Sheep"), and probably to "The Hero" and "The Samian." The Epitrepontes is a play in six acts, and treats of a theme beloved of Greek playwrights : a betrayed maiden, a child whose birth is a secret to everybody but the mother; and the complications which arise give the author free scope for the exercise of his imagination and art in dialogue.

In the case of Menander, his popularity depended not on his -plots, but on the facility with which he transformed old types and served them up to his audience in a brillant picture of contemporary manners, adorned with the choicest flowers of language. In the Epitre| pontes, Smikrines is all that the good judge should be, with, nevertheless, a few natural defects of temper which give life and truth to the character. Perhaps the judgment scene is the best of the fragments discovered. Smikrines is going down the street, absorbed in his own private affairs, when Daos, the Tshepherd, and Syriskos, the charcoal burner. meet him, and ask him to decide between them At first he sends them about their business with the words, "Yon poor wretches with skins on your backs begin talking to me about points of law !" But on their persisting and promising to abide by his sentence, he consents to hear them, "for, after all, why should I not ?" and he gives the word to Daos, who seems to him the less garrulous of the two.

Daos then tells how, a month ago, when feeding his flock, he picked up a little child in a wood who was wearing a necklace and trinkets. Hereu pon Syriskos tries to break in, but Smikrines reproves him : "If you interrupt I shall strike you with my staff." Daos con tinues his tale, to the effect that he met Syriskos, and told him that he was sorry he had picked up the child, as he did not know what to do with it. "Then, before I could finish, Syriskos began saying. '0, Daos, may you prosper in all your undertakings,' and, enumerating all the good things that I might desire, ending up with, "Give me the child, and may you be happy and free from care ! I have a wife who has just had and lost an infant,' by whom he meant that woman there, who is holding the child in her arms.,'
"You begged him, Syriskos ?"
"I did so, your honoar."

Daos: "He persecuted me all day long, flattering and arguing so deftly that at last I consented. I gave him the child, and he went away covering me with blessings, and even taking my hands and kissing them." After thinking it over, however, Syriskos came to the conclusion that it he took the child he ought also to have the jewellery she wore, but Daos did not agree with him. "Alone I found her, and you, who were not even there, want every thing! To put it shortly, I freely gave you something that was mine. If this gift pleases you still, keep it ; but if it does not, restore it to me, and so will you not be wronged by me I nor I by you. In any case, you cannot have all, the half by goodwill and the other half by compelling me. I have said what I had to say."
"He has said his say I Don't you hear him? He has spoken ! (says the judge)."

"Certainly. Now it is my turn !" And then Syriskos replies. He admits the truth of what Daos has related, but, speaking in the name of the child, and as its guardian, he claims the objects, not for his own profit, but that at some future date they may serve to establish her identity. And he cites the example of Neleus and Pelias the famous heroes, who, in similar case, from being shepherds became kings. "I have spoken. Judge as it seems right to you."

"It is easy to judge this case. Everything that was on the child belongs to it." Thus briefly Smikrines gives his judgment. "But the child itself ?" says Daos. "I shall not decide in the favour of you, who only wish it evil, but rather of the man who wishes to defend its interests against you, who seek to damage them."

Daos remonstrates, but is forced to submit. Smikrines takes away the bag which holds the fortune of the child, gives it to Syriskos, and trudges off without another thought of the matter. The pleading is happy, but happier still is the manner in which Smikrines acquits himself of the functions thrust upon him. He scaroely opens his mouth whilst the two are disputing, but his few short questions are admirably calculated to bring out the honesty and good heart of Syriskos.

This find is the more interesting since, up to now, the reputation which we have allowed to Menander is only a continuation of that which he enjoyed amongst his contemporaries, whilst we deplored the loss of the comedies on which it rested. Now, however, we can judge for our selves whether Cæsar's estimate is true, that "Terence was half of Menander. In these fragments we can compare the two, and see that the heroes are drawn with a stronger hand, the sitnations more forcible, and the style more mervous. But the characters are conventional, and the subjects of threadbare interest. What used to compensate for the poverty of the drama was the purity of style and humour rather than the truth or drollery of the obsery nations, and there are few now to whom Greek is sufficiently familiar to enable them to enjoy these qualities like the original audiences did. Professor Maspero concludes his notice, from which the above extracts are taken, with the remark, "Menander will be a treat for a few who will willingly sing his praises, but for the rest of the world he will remain what he was before, a great man on the faith of others."

div.head: FINANCES OF THE VATICAN.
div.p: The present condition of the Papal Finances is the subject of an exhaustive article in a French review. The expenditure Budget, which in the time of Leo XIII, amounted to about 10,000,000 lire, bas under Pius X. been reduced to 8,000,000 lire. Pope Pius X. is very economical, at any rate as regards his own person. The greater part of the Papal expenditure is for the upkeep of the Court and the numerous active and pensioned officials, while 500,000 lire is set aside for education and charitable purposes. No longer has the Pope any Civil List to aid him to meet this expenditure. It is true that the Italian Government has decreed to the Pope a subsidy of 3,225,000 | lire, which was approximately the amount of the Civil List at the Church States, but the Vatican, which does not profess to recognise the Kingdom of Italy, has never accepted this subsidy, which in the course of years would have increased to an enormous sum, bad not the Italian Government ordered for its own security that every five years the interest should lapse. Therefore all expenditure has had to be met by the private Papal income, which is chiefly derived from the sale of bulls, the traffic in posts and titles, and from the Peter's Pence. The Papal bulls bring in from 1.000.000 to 2,000,000 lire. The sale of titles plays an important part in the Papal Budget. Papal dukes, counts, and barons are freely appointed; bardly & day passes without a fresh addition to the nobility being registered at the Vatican. A ducal title costs 100,000 lire, while to be made a count costs 20,000 lire, and to be made a baronet about 10,000 lire.

The chief source of income, however, is Peter's Pence. The amount for this fund col lected in Germany, France, England, and America totals about 2,000,000 lire, Spain contributing 800,000 lire and Italy practically nothing The Italian Catholics, and especially those of Rome, have an indestructible belief that the whole world is for the Pope and the Pope is for the Romanis. Only lately, at the Lateran Church in Rome, proudly called the Mother of Churches, on a special festival a collection was made for the benefit of Peter's Pence, at which the result was only 35 lire. The main portion of Peter's Pence comes from France, where, however, the amount has been steadily diminishing during the last few years; but great efforts are now being made to popularise this fund, and on November 16, 1908, special collections will be made through out the churches, that day being the jubilee of Pope Pius X

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: In order to raise additional recruits for the Royal Dublin Pusiliers, recruiting for that ancient regiment has been opened in the North Irish Regimental District.
The troop ship "Assaye" left Southampton yesterday with over 1000 troops on board for various regiments in India. The "Assaye" will call at Port Said on the 15th inst.

Colonel James Magill, C.B. Royal Army Medical Corps, for the past few years P.M.O. at Cairo, now retires on his well earned pension of £689 per annem. He rendered fine service up the Nile in the Expedition of 188485 for the relief of Gordon, then shut up in the Khartoum ; and in the South African War his very valuable services were recognised by a well earned C.B.
The cruiser "Europa" will arrive at Port Said on the 21st inst. en voyage to Colombo, Ceylon, to where she is carrying a relief crew for the "Powerful," flagship of the Australian Squadron.
The Fourth Cruiser Squadron will leave England on the 3rd prox. for a cruise to Gibraltar and Aranci Bay, Sardinia, arriving at the latter point on the last day of the month.

The cruiser Sappho" will leave Chatham on the 17th inst. with reliefs for distribution amongst the destroyers on the Mediterranean Station. The battleship "Glory," which leaves for the same destination about the same date, also brings out additional ratings for various ships.

A new pattern forage cap has been approved for substantive colonels not on the staff. It will have as a badge the Royal crest in em broidery, the peak being plain gold embroidery, (infantry pattern) inch wide. The band will be of blue cloth, 15 inches wide, between scarlet borders, with a scarlet welt

Scout sergeants and first class scouts in battalions will in future wear a brass fleur-de lis badge, with bar below, on the right arm above the elbow on tunics and all jackets. In the case of non-commissioned officers the the hadge will be above their chevrons.
September 7th.
Lieutenant W. H. Whyte, Royal Dublin Pusiliers, lately with the 1st Battalion at Alexandria, has been placed on half pay owing to ill health

Lieutenant C. A. Howard, 4th Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been promoted to fill the vacancy for a captain in that regiment. He gets the triple stars at nine years service, having originally entered the King's Shropshire Light Infantry in August, 1898, transferred to the Rifles in January, 1901, and Baw a good deal of service in South Africa with the South African Light Horse (Queen's medal with four clasps.)

It has been notified that sword-bayonets of the 1908 pattern cannot at present be supplied for units of the Royal Engineers, Royal Garri son Artillery, Army Service Corps and Army Ordnance Corps at home which are being re-armed with the short rifle; and, therefore the 1888 pattern sword-bayonet must be retained by these troops. Men who are going abroad during the trooping will be provided with the new weapon.

One of the most expensive items of warfare, either on land or sen, nowadays is that of big gun ammunition. A protracted campaign would cripple a small state in that matter alone. For instance the ordinary cordite shell fired from the 9.2 gun costs £14 188. a common shell filled with lyddite costs £12 88. 9d. a steel shell for armour piercing, filled with lyddite, costs £14 129. 3d, whilst each solid steel shot for armour piercing represents a value of £25 17s. For the bin guns each cordite cartridge costs £2 12s. a common shell filled with lyddite costs £8 189.

The battleship "Glory" will be commissioned at Portsmouth on the 18th inst. and not as previously stated, by Captain R.8. Phipps Hornby as flagship of Prince Louis of Battenberg, second in command of the Mediterranean. Fleet. Captain Phipps Hornby is a member of famous naval and military family which bas done great work in Empire building. He entered the service in January, 1879, took five "firsts" at his examination for promotion, became commander in 1898, and captain in 1908, and was a middy of the battleship "Alexandra" at the bombardment of Alexandria, July, 1882 (Egyptian medal with "Alexandria" clasp, and the Khedive's star).

div.head: EGYPTIAN YARNS IN LANCASHIRE
div.p: Mr. W. Tattersall, writing in the "Financier" of Monday week says :

Yarns made from Egyptian cotton in the Bolton district and South Lancashire are about the strongest thing in the market. A very fair turn-over has occurred, especially in the finer numbers of combed descriptions, Spinners are difficult to deal with, and in many cases adopt a very independent attitude to buyers. Users find full rates have to be paid for anything wanted. Some producers are behind with deliveries, and much inconvenience is being caused to manufacturers. The margin in most counts and qualities is healthy and remunerative, and in this section of our trade a healthy business is secured for several months to come. In the special marks long delivery has to be given for orders now entered.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication un emplacement gazonné dans le Grand Jardin Nousha de la superficie de 3 feddans environ pour café pablic et restaurant
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau des Pares et Plantations où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés
Les offres devront être adresses sous pli cacheté Monsieur le Vice President de la Municipalité avant le ler Octobre prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: Soumission pour la location de café au Grand Jardin Nouzha
Le cautionnement préva au cahier des charges, devra être versé an Service de la Comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le ler Octobre de 9 h. à midi.
Toate offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions cids Mr Snartte
Si les offres ne sont satisfaisantes, la Municipalité n'est pas tenue de les accepter.
Alexandrie le 14/9/07.
Le Vice-President.
30915-3-2(signé) Dr SCHIESS

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
